item.title: How to Choose the Right New Hampshire Loan Officer for Your Situation
item.description:
How to Choose the Right New Hampshire Loan Officer for Your Situation

Not all loan officers are created equal. Some specialize in first-time buyers, others in jumbo loans or seasonal properties. Choosing the right NH loan officer can save thousands and prevent application disasters.

Questions to Ask Before Committing

  1. How many lenders do you work with? (Look for 10+ wholesale sources)
  2. Do you handle [your specific program]? (NHHFA, VA, jumbo, etc.)
  3. How many closings in my area last year? (Local experience matters)
  4. Can you provide references? (Talk to past clients)
  5. What’s your typical closing timeline? (30–45 days is standard)

Red Flags to Avoid

  • Pressure to apply immediately (good loan officers educate first)
  • Vague fee explanations (request a detailed Loan Estimate)
  • No local experience (out-of-state loan officers miss NH nuances)
  • One-size-fits-all advice (your situation should drive recommendations)

Specialization Matters

First-time buyers: Choose loan officers who are NHHFA-approved and experienced with down payment assistance programs.

item.title: Why New Hampshire Loan Officers Beat National Call Centers on Local Properties
item.description:
Why New Hampshire Loan Officers Beat National Call Centers on Local Properties

National online lenders offer convenience and speed—until you hit a property that doesn’t fit their automated underwriting. That’s when local New Hampshire loan officers win.

Where National Lenders Struggle in NH

  1. Seasonal homes: Automated systems often reject Lake Region properties
  2. Portsmouth condos: HOA reviews and condo rules trip up call center processors
  3. Investment properties: National lenders use strict formulas that don’t account for local rental markets
  4. Self-employment: Cookie-cutter income calculations miss nuanced business structures

item.title: NHHFA Programs and How New Hampshire Loan Officers Help You Qualify
item.description:
NHHFA Programs and How New Hampshire Loan Officers Help You Qualify

New Hampshire Housing Finance Authority (NHHFA) programs offer down payment assistance and below-market rates for qualified first-time buyers. But navigating income limits, property caps, and application requirements can be complex.

What NHHFA Offers

  1. Lower interest rates (often 0.25%–0.50% below market)
  2. Down payment assistance (up to $15,000 in some programs)
  3. Flexible credit requirements (620+ accepted in many cases)
  4. First-time buyer and repeat buyer options
